Definition: In this task, you are given a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to classify the comment into two classes: toxic and non-toxic. Toxicity is defiend as anything that is rude, disrespectful, or unreasonable, and would make someone want to leave a converation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: i am just sorry that khadr didnt get a bullet in the head before he blew the head off that innocent father because his islamic boogie skywizard told him to.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it advocates acts of violence.
This is a non-toxic comment because it is not rude or desrespectful.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: "racism" -appears to be the only card in your deck!?
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks of racism but does not disrespect any race.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: Fat ass, go eat another do-nut.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be toxic because it disrespects the people that are overweight.

Comment: Almost three-quarters of all reported and unreported sexual assaults involve nothing more than unwanted touching. The law then prosecutes unwanted touching under the same section as it does a violent sexual attack. Surely there must be a better way to deal with this majority of sexual misdemeanors than through the criminal justice system.

The law does two things by making both the alleged victim and the accused face the heavy burden of a criminal court in all cases of sexual assault. First it discourages victims from reporting. Second it ensures that the accused fights tooth and nail to avoid conviction, with all the additional trauma that may mean for the complainant.

Take minor sexual indiscretions out of the criminal justice system. By lowering the legal stakes in the matter, more victims will be willing to report and more accused may be willing to accept some form of restorative justice.

Comment: Why do we keep changing the Superintendent?  After hiring new Superintendents and paying more money, what do we expect is going to happen?  Do you all think that the student performance is going to suddenly rise to the top?  If so, you are all dreaming.

In general, the key to good student performance in the school lies with the parents and family.  Look around and you can see that many Hawaii families are not ones that produce high academic achievement.  We have too many children that come from uneducated and even poor parents who don't care much if their children finish school.  Yes, there are exceptions but they are too few and will succeed no matter who the Superintendent is or even who their teachers are.

We would be better off if the Board of Education were replaced with people who recognize our situation and work with it and not expect miracles.

Comment: It's sad to read the many negative comments about teacher's salaries and benefits, especially considering 35 plus students per class. Unfortunately, it's not unusual, in all parts of the country.  I was in high school teaching for four years in California. Left as soon as I could, partly for the lack of support from local school board and community.  Fortunately, the National Science Foundation paid me to get my M.S. degree in Chemistry with all fees covered. I quickly moved on to an outstanding community college at one of the highest paying colleges in the country.  The respect from community, administration, and students was the difference between night and day.  

By having decent salaries and benefits, Eugene is able to attract the better teachers from all parts of the country.  Consider this (baby sitting wages): $10 an hour per student times 35 students equals $350 per class.  Five classes at $1750 a day times 190 days equals $332,500 per year.  $103,000 a year is a bargain!

Comment: good lord. The lack of logic of some of you is nothing less than amazing. 
1) when you buy a COMPUTER, it has a CPU in it. Some are rated at say 2.0 ghz, and others at 3.0 ghz. These are the EXACT SAME CPU. The difference is that the 3.0 rated was fully tested at 3.0 ghz and work at it. OTOH, the 2.0 was tested at 2.0 and not tested at 3.0. Yet, 99% of them will run at 3.0 JUST FINE. But you paid say $150 for the 2.0 OR you would have paid $500 for the 3.0. What is difference? Just the speed at which they ran the EXACT SAME TEST. 
This is true on YOUR PHONE. On any laptop, etc.  How do you obtain the faster speed? By changing the software. This is just 1 example of this. 

2) Tesla sold you a car with a set amount of charge capabilities. At the same time, they TOLD YOU that at any time, if you want, you can pay extra and the software will upgrade it. So, what do you care if somebody pays for the extra miles / charge? As it is, tesla's profit margins are low on the 60 due to this.

Comment: Your comment reveals you know just enough about public school funding to pretend you actually understand it. No Child Left Behind (2001) conditioned federal education funds on standardized testing focused initiatives and scores. Feds put in about 12-15% of HIDOE's $2 billion+ annual budget, not the majority by far, but $250 million you can't afford to lose. The standardized testing requirements, incentivized (basically forced) districts to mostly drop art, music, PE, even social studies and science at first, to fund "test score chasing." This was contrary to what the research suggests is most effective, but money talks. Ku's right about Obama not doing much to fix it; in fact Race to the Top (2009) probably accelerated the trend in Hawaii. ESSA (2015) provides somewhat more flexibility, but only taking effect now. Otherwise, Ku is a kook on this subject, too. He'd do better to go home and kook rice.

Comment: The economics of movie-making now encourage mindless entertainment which does not depend on shared cultural references. 

There is more money to be made with movies that sell globally, i.e. the lowest common denominator, than with complex, introspective, chatty movies that depend on people "getting"  the cultural subtleties.

Comment: A rather delayed response. Imagine that a retailer sells chicken for R 30/kg. The retailer has an invoice price for that chicken of R 25/kg meaning a R 5 GP. Written into the supply agreement is that the chicken supplier will pay for various marketing expenses via rebates, shelf fees etc. which costs the supplier R 5/kg.  The chicken supplier nets R 20/kg. If the retailer paid for all the marketing costs themselves the chicken supplier still gets R 20/kg, the retailer still sells the chicken for R 30/kg but the retailer GP is now R 10/kg. This changes the way the retailers books are presented.

Comment: I moved here in 2013...from Oceanside.  I was only in Oceanside for 2 years.  I was born an raised in Sonoma County for 45 years (18 of those on a small farm which became a shopping center).  My family (mother, grandparents, etc) are all from OR.  They left when my mom was 12 for better employment opportunities in CA.  They returned when I was 18.  I spent every summer in Prineville and Baker City.  I have one brother near Eugene and one near Olympia.  And yes, I also roll my eyes when I see California plates.  Only because I saw how the "haves" wreaked havoc on our housing prices there.  Now I see the same thing happening to Portland.  I don't want to live in a land of the "haves", entitlement, and excess....I left that land.  I want to live in a land of diversity, and compassion for the have-nots.

Comment: This report really hits home for me. The real issue is that both young and old use their phone when they are driving or walking in public. These individuals believe that they can handle it. Reality hits when an accident occurs. Reality hit for me in 2008: my 11-year old was walking home from school - half-way through a crosswalk with the light still green and not on his phone - and he was hit by a large SUV that ran a red light. The driver was a mother who was on her phone and her kids were in the back seat. From police report, my son was thrown 140 feet. He survived. The woman's license was suspended in lieu of imprisonment. Almost 9 years later, my son is still piecing together his life. His little sister said it best: you can add up the medical bills and missing days from school, but you cannot bring back his fun-loving spirit; our family life was shattered. Is it worth it? Is it about your entitlement to your phone? Or is it more?

The reported disclosure by Trump to the Russians is a totally insignificant drop in an Atlantic Ocean-sized "intelligence-sharing".

Comment: I am Jewish and can only speak to that.  The more liberal sects of Judaism (Reform and Reconstructionist) seem to be closer to what you are looking for.  Not there, but closer.  One of the things that both tend to push, especially in regards to some of the laws that look a little odd to modern people, is this idea of, if it is meaningful to you, then do it.  So do or don't keep kosher depending on how meaningful to you it is.  For some, that might mean just avoiding pork for others, it means not worrying about it at all.

The chosen people thing has always bugged me a bit, as well.  I do like the idea of tikkun olam (repairing the world).  I liken it to "the campsite rule", where you leave this world a little better than it was when you came into it.  This doesn't mean converting people, or doing good things to buy a golden ticket to heaven, it means doing good, to make the world today a better place, that might mean charity or helping at Habitat, or something else.

Comment: I am 70 years old, spent much of my life in the woods around here, been charged by grizzly bears and black bears (and moose) and I'm still alive.  I always carry bear spray.  It is not that hard to co-exist with wildlife if you are situationally aware, know something about the behavior of our local wildlife, and try to avoid killing our non-human locals.  If you don't like living with wildlife, move to California, IMHO.  There are always some risks when living in Alaska.  This remains a unique and spectacular place to live!  Without wildlife, it would quickly get boring!

Comment: DOA. The Senate was smart enough to remove it from their agenda. It is often said, "if it ain't broke, don't fix it." There is nothing wrong with the FAA or its ATC system. Best on the globe.

Comment: You want proof? I switched to being a private investor this year. Started selling my funds at the end of January: put more than 1/2 the money in high interest savings and term deposits and invested the rest in equities, starting in May. I had absolutely no experience when I started. Just did a whole lot of reading and talked to people who've been investing for years. Invested mainly in blue chips. For fun, I check the performance of my old funds on a daily basis. Here's where things stand today, 4 months after taking the plunge: 1) my old TFSA fund, 1.33% YTD; my new TFSA, 6.51%; 2) my old RRSP fund, 0.76 % YTD; I have two new RRSPs: one in a savings account at @ 2.10%, the other invested in the market is at 3.21%: the plan is to invest more in equities as I gain more experience; 3) my old RRIF fund is at minus 0.30% YTD; my new RRIF is earning 2.40%. So, in four months, and with no experience, my investments are doing better than with an advisor. Draw your own conclusions...

Comment: There are several problems with "natural law". There are multiple definitions of the term. One is "the law written in human hearts" (see Aquinas' Summa Theologica, I-II, q 94, art 6.) Another is "what is found in nature". (There is a third, having to do with legal theories.)

In practice, "natural law" can be misused in several ways:

It can mean nothing more than "this is what is written in my heart", which is the same as "in my opinion". Personal opinion is not a good basis for moral or dogmatic teachings.

It can be invoked when the person does not have an actual argument. A good example is in Humanae Vitae 4, which says essentially "we know the natural law, and you will just have to take our word for it". That's not an argument, that's blather.

When it does not actually describe how nature works. Humanae Vitae says that in nature, sexual intercourse is used for procreation. In fact, many of the great apes use it for pair bonding. So the author of HV got it wrong.

Comment: The thing about political polls is that they are, at best, an educated guess, and if you make enough guesses sooner or later some of them are going to be correct even if they seem like outliers.

Straight-up polling doesn't necessarily work for politics and election because it is subject to all kinds of systematic error.  Some of this shows up as sampling errors (ie the people who answer the phone call for your survey are not representative of the population as a whole) while other times it is simply a reporting bias (ie supporters of Marine Le Pen might be more likely than supports of Emmanuel Macron to say they are "undecided voters" because she is a controversial candidate).

The end result is that you can't apply standard statistics so any numbers are, at best, a guess.

What does that mean for France?  Who knows.  Mr. Marcron seems like the sensible choice to most but he, much like Hillary Clinton in the U.S., represents the status quo that so many are frustrated with.

Comment: Cracked column basalt and a transition forest that goes from oak savannah to rain forest conifer to rain shadow pine to oak savannah to high desert.   The slides will be released by water freezing and expanding,  and then thawing,  and rain lubricating the now loosened rocks.   Freezing is one of the important factors.  And rain on frozen ground can be a flash flood event.

Dead,  burned trees,  rot at the mean annual winter  snow level,  be that one foot   or four or more.  You can actually accurately guess the mean annual winter snow level by the height of the stumps from  blowdown in a burn area.  The real danger over time will be snag toboggans rocketing towards the railroad and freeway.....or the back of your home.  

Salvage log or not (that area is mostly helicopter logging ground),  the dead trees will fall.  The issue is who gets to control the aftermath.  My life experience includes fire watch duties,  and when the afternoon humidity dropped,  trees fell.  Wet rot dried out.

Comment: The Sioux, including Sitting Bull and Red Cloud accepted the terms of the Treaty of 1868 which placed the northern boundary at the 46th parallel and the Missouri River. Well south of the area of the pipeline. In 1873 an executive order was enacted that moved the border north to the Cannon Ball River, again well south of the pipeline location. The Sioux have accepted the treaty terms for that last 148 years. I would say that kind of trumps your argument, (pun intended). The treaty ;problems are with the Treaty of 1877 that was done without the consent of the Sioux as required by the Treaty  of 1868. It also broke up the one big reservation into several smaller reservations and took away the Black Hills, but the Sioux, rightfully, have never accepted the Treaty of 1877. I think they never should accept the Treaty of 1877. However, in every case, the northern boundary is the Cannon Ball River, still well south of the pipeline due to an executive order in 1873 moving the boundary north.

Comment: Actually, there is an office in West Virginia, run by the ATFE that handles firearm tracking and identification for the federal government. Using information provided from gun sales and state registration, guns found at crime scenes can be linked to buyers/owners and used to further/solve criminal cases.

It's called the National Tracing Center, https://www.atf.gov/firearms/national-tracing-center

Tragically the NRA managed to slip provisions into the law in the late 80s that hamstrings the NTC because it won't let them use computers to do the searches, its painstaking labor through literally piles of paperwork. It was covered here: http://www.businessinsider.com/heres-how-cops-actually-trace-a-gun-2016-8

Also Canada closed its LONG-gun registry, due to budget restraints in 2012 and did not change license requirements. See, the RCMP says so: http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/cfp-pcaf/online_en-ligne/reg_enr-eng.htm

Comment: The guys camped out on the Punchbowl off, they are on State property and the city has to move on problems one at a time. There is no magic bullet to solve all of them. If HPD had to arrest all the homeless on their beats, there would be no police officers left to take care of the other problems. There aren't enough detention facilities to house them. And courts would be backed up. I am only citing things that were done in the past. There were some wins, geographical restrictions was great for me as a watch commander in China town. Yup moved problem but I was also realistic about what the police department  and my officers could do. Restrictions was a temporary solution but it brought together the Chinatown Neighborhood board, the Honolulu Prosecutors, and the Courts, community policing. By the way thanks for being part of community policing, sounds like you were part of a neighborhood watch program. If you have no soultions going forward, maybe we need to look back and see what worked.

Comment: Those are not equivalent.

The difference is that a prayer room is for actual, you know, believers, to perform a religious ritual of their actual, current, religious belief. It is a mini mosque, temple, church, etc.

The crucifix in the Quebec N.A. is an historical artefact reflective of Quebec's cultural heritage, which does not reflect current religious beliefs or rituals of Quebecers any more than having the fleur-de-lys on the flag represents current belief in loyalty to the King of France.

Insisting on destroying  traces of one's religious past in the name of current secularism should be as abhorrent as the destruction of monuments of past religions by ISIS, or France destroying Notre Dame Cathedral or Chartres in the name of secularism. Ironically, Catholicism is a crucial part of the culture of Quebec, because that is what people rebelled against. 

I personally don't care whether it stays or goes, but I object to the mischaracterization of what it represents.

Comment: And then there is hearsay in court, courtesy of FindLaw » Learn About The Law » Criminal Law » Criminal Procedure » "Hearsay" Evidence:
---
"The rule against hearsay is deceptively simple and full of exceptions. Hearsay is an out of court statement, made in court, to prove the truth of the matter asserted. In other words, hearsay is evidence of a statement that was made other than by a witness while testifying at the hearing in question and that is offered to prove the truth of the matter stated. For example, Witness A in a murder trial claimed on the stand: "Witness B (the "declarant") told me that the defendant killed the victim." The definition of hearsay is not too difficult to understand. But the matter can become very confusing when one considers all of the many exceptions to the general rule against hearsay..."
----

Comment: I've read the decision again, and apologize for saying she acted as translator during the making of the will. Here's what the judge wrote:
"[86]        Le testateur, de langue et de culture étrangère n’a pas compris le sens du testament rédigé par la notaire, malgré les instructions qu’il lui avait données et qui ont été corroborées par sa sœur Roza.

"[87]        Le testament du 29 août 2013 est donc invalide et sans effets pour cause d’erreur qui a vicié son consentement, car s’il avait réalisé la teneur de testament tel que rédigé, il ne l’aurait pas signé puisqu’il ne reflétait pas ses dernières volontés.

"[88]        Ainsi donc, c’est la fausse croyance du leg devant être ultimement transmis à ses enfants qui est la cause de la nullité du testament."

Comment: Smart meters are a buggy whip technology plagued by early obsolescence that hinders vs. helps us move to a renewable energy future that benefits us all.  You can go to www.gettingsmarteraboutthesmartgrid.org and also www.smartgridawareness.org for well researched articles on the downside of smart meters. When one sees what has happened in others states where Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) has been deployed for several years or more, one clearly sees there are NO benefits to consumers for this costly boondoggle coming our way.  It simply benefits the wireless industries, utilities, and third party marketers. The AMI program costs millions of dollars and is not needed to have a true smart grid.  AMI will increase cybersecurity threats, privacy risks, fire, and unjustified billing increases. Until any technology used on this massive scale is safe and they actually make meters that protect consumers, everyone should keep their analog electro-mechanical meters or return to them.

Comment: Nope.  Jesus missed the ["institution of a priesthood"] by at least a century, or more.  You going need to search a long time to find scriptural basis in the NT for your assertion.  

The authorship of Hebrews is uncertain - Eusebius, the Greek historian and polemicist of Christianity (314 AD) had his doubts about Paul's authorship .  But we do know that it was written most likely in Rome - therefore it presents a christology that is a backwards look in time.

Scholars believe the Book of Hebrews - very polished and eloquent - was written for Jewish Christians.  Its purpose was to exhort Christians to persevere in the face of persecution. The theme of the epistle is the doctrine of the person of Christ and his role as mediator between God and humanity - which eventually did become a major tenet in Christianity's priesthood cult.

Comment: " what constitutes sexual assault"
I would go even further. When someone hears "sexual assault" they think "rape" but in fact sexual assault covers a very wide range of behaviours. The inclusion of things like an unwanted kiss into the same overarching category of sexual assault that includes rape may make it seem like there is an epidemic of rape. 
A million dollar bank robbery and a $10 shoplift are both theft but if all we talked about was the total number of thefts it could seem like there is an epidemic of bank robberies happening on every street corner. That why have theft over $5,000 and theft under $5,000, and people use those terms to ensure a clear picture is being given.
If we wanted clear, useful and informed discussion on the issues by the public we would have very different names for each class of sexual assault, just like we have "theft" and "theft under $5,000",  and writers would use those category names when writing. And clarity is what we all want, right?

Comment: "The Empire State Building was constructed in one year and closed no surface streets. Sound Transit could do the work it needs in two years or less, leaving time to consider better alternatives, including technologies that were not available when Sound Transit planned East Link."

The Empire State Building is a building, not a train network, and it was built before there were regulations in place to keep workers safe. This is such a silly comparison it hardly deserves a rebuttal, but it's made so often that people believe it has merit. It doesn't. 

As for how quickly ST *could* complete the project, it could be sped up greatly if restrictions on nighttime and weekend construction were curtailed, but somehow I doubt Mercer Island residents would be crazy about that prospect either.

Comment: Most of the nine groups initially given status are tied to the legal profession; a few were religious in nature. None of the LGBT groups that applied were granted status. The perception clearly is that were not 'enough groups representing both sides'. 

Appeal courts have previously ruled that a key criteria for inclusion is the probative value of the input likely to be offered. Ostensibly Wagner took the view that the position of the LGBT community was already well documented in the submissions before it and, hence, that any additional argument was likely to be redundant. But the public doesn't always understand these nuances; and so as not to give rise to any apprehension of bias, it would have been wiser had some of LGBT groups been included. 

But two wrongs don't make a right. Better the court had issued the aforementioned explanation than to open itself to criticism that it could be swayed by whichever groups shouts the loudest. Its independence and integrity are paramount.

Comment: "Logging will transfer vast amounts of carbon from the forest to the atmosphere ..."  Not necessarily. When you cut down a tree, you eliminate it's ability to store carbon in the future, but the products made from those trees still store that carbon ... it's locked up in the wood product. A tree that falls and rots stores some carbon in the soil, but most is released to the atmosphere. When trees operate in a system, forests are great carbon sinks, no doubt, but I think you're overestimating the value of a small patch of trees here that are not part of a larger forest system ... trees that are apparently getting knocked down by storms and probably rotting, based on other comments here. You'll get nearly as much carbon storage cutting and replanting as you will leaving them to rot in such a small clump.

Comment: One would assume that in a legitimately objective legal system the courts (and especially a Supreme Court) must permit input from all relevant stakeholders. By deselecting LGBTQ intervenors in a case where LGBTQ rights and interests are fundamental to the matter at hand, the SCC's original position failed the test of objectivity. Imagine if the SCC were to hear and rule on an appeal application about a pipeline in northern Canada after deselecting intervenors representing aboriginal interests. It just wouldn't happen. And it shouldn't happen, just as it shouldn't in a case where LGBTQ interests as well as the legitimate right of LGBTQ citizens/residents to be protected from discrimination are at stake. This is not about special interests. It's about the right of people from a historically oppressed community to be able to protect themselves from discrimination. To shut them out of the process would have transformed the SCC into little more than a kangaroo court.

Comment: Yes, it would be lovely if we agreed this should be the first of our "traditional doctrines." St. Justin Martyr knew Greek philosophy very well, and the philosophical schools all hold "reason," "logos," in high regard in one way or another (it becomes an especially important technical term among the Stoics), Plato being the first to make a direct association between human beings' mental faculties and the transcendent. And of course this celebration of the practice of using our heads, doubting, questioning, exploring, speculating, judging, evaluating, being "critical" in the correct sense of that Greek-origin word, is not much in evidence in the biblical tradition.

Rufinus quotes one of the Desert Fathers he interviewed, giving an excellent Platonic answer to a question about the origin of the virtues: "The mother of all the virtues is diákrisis," that word meaning discernment, discretion, and discrimination, all at once.

Comment: What the DOT neglects to inform the public, is that licensing fees for "alternative" fuel vehicles are already Hundreds of dollars higher than gasoline powered vehicles. My natural gas powered vehicle has an alternative-fuel license-renewal surcharge of $275 Each Year. Where is that money spent ?  And what is the state going to do with the 49.4 cents/gallon gas tax once the road-usage-tax is enacted ?  I'll never believe that the state will just remove it.  What does the state have planned for the folks who live in border towns, like Vancouver, and work out of state, say, in Portland ?  Or, how about inter-state freight haulers who drive a few hundred miles in Washington & a few thousand miles out  a of state (or even freight haulers who drive into Washington, drop of their freight, then drive right back out, how will they pay their road-usage-tax ?)  I think this is just another ruse to reach into our wallets under the guise of fairness for those who drive less efficient vehicles.

Comment: Nobody - because I said nothing about ideas being tolerable. I spoke of ideas being tolerANT or not. And that is an extremely easy thing to determine. Your idea is tolerant if, and only if, part of that idea is that you have to tolerate me and my ideas. It's a very simple quod-pro-quo calculation. I must tolerate your views even if I disagree with them - as long as you do the same for me. If your view is that I should be cut into tiny little pieces and fed to the dogs, I'm not obligated to tolerate that view. If your view is that I should not be allowed to express my views - then I'm not obligated to tolerate that view and I am justified to prevent you expressing it so that all the many other views can remain safe to express.

Comment: Interesting time living out on the west coast. Day by day the radio reported fewer and fewer local commercial planes flying until even the twin turbo-props didn't fly. And waking up on Saturday morning in the middle of that spell, -46º in spite of the "warm" marine influence, and the village was silent. The recoil start on the snowmachine would barely return; one pull and then it very slowly crept back for another try. So while it was doing that, I pulled the plugs and brought them inside and heated them on the propane stove to help them along. When the engine finally came to life, I let 'er run the rest of the day in case some form of transport was needed in a hurry.

Comment: As others have pointed out, you could have literally hundreds of cyclists (or thousands of pedestrians) using a roadway before you did as much damage as a single car. The shift wasn't merely a change in volume, but towards a form of transportation that demanded, by its nature, near-exclusive use of the right-of-way; needed unprecedented investments in infrastructure to be viable; and which, as mentioned, resulted in ballooning maintenance costs.

Also, I think you underestimate the volume of traffic before the advent of cars. Congestion was an urban issue long before the Industrial Revolution. Urbanization pre-automobile made it worse. A busy NYC street in 1903, for instance, likely contained more people than could fit on a modern roadway, since single-occupancy vehicles make inefficient use of space.

The bottom line is cars cost the public in unique ways; gas taxes and motor vehicle fees were initiated in a conscious acknowledgment of that. Bikes weren't omitted as an oversight.

Comment: Using a hypothetical example will only produce a hypothetical reality. The example is too ideal and enticing. It does not represent most of our retirees. It fails to include possible issues and crisis that our retirees will face during retirement. It did not discuss how the couple would face health problems and staggering health care costs. Instead, they laced it with the awesome feeling of being able to travel during retirement. Healthcare costs, if not tackled carefully, can deplete their savings despite having Medicare. We, at FreeMedSuppQuotes, encourages people to plan their health, not just today but also in the future. We encourage them to get to know various healthcare options so that they know which one of them can provide the best benefits without hurting their finances. Medicare, Medicare supplement plans, long term care insurance, Medicaid, etc. if they know the advantages of each one, it can provide them the benefits when the need arises. A good adviser tackles the reality

Comment: Not sure where the drug company 5% R&D figure is coming from?

In Canada there are multiple R&D tax credits individual companies can claim. When you combine the R&D tax credits (Provincial and Federal), drug companies can receive roughly 25% in R&D tax credits in Ontario each year. The combined percentage various by Province, being based in Ontario or Quebec results in the highest R&D tax credits.

Comment: Sean Maney,
There is a real "hole" in the system that does back ground checks for OCS and other agencies (private) that rely on it.
If a person has lost their "professional" license to be a mental health social worker or counselor because they had a sexual relationship with one of their juvenile clients in another state (Washington for example) but for some reason was never criminally charged, that person can move to Alaska and go to work at a agency that requires background checks and that person will pass. Or, if you are an attorney who has sexually inappropriate actions with a client they were appointed to represent and they are either disbarred or surrender their license in Alaska, they can move to Nome or Bethel and volunteer to coach a youth soccer team. That will not show up on the OCS background check because there were no criminal charges. 
I have pointed this out to OCS and other agencies but nothing was done. Our state representative was also contacted, nothing happened.

Comment: Well, Rolling Stone is an odd choice of an authority about anonymous sources: http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/05/business/media/rolling-stone-rape-story-case-guilty.html?_r=0 ... When The Washington Post uses an anonymous source, like it did in Watergate (http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/politics/special/watergate/), the publication is on the line for its veracity. The Washington Post has created a lot of credibility for its work over at least the past 40 years, and it has not chosen to use those types of sources lightly (although one could argue that it has become less discerning in recent years, due to increased competition). Regardless, WaPo follows very strict protocols for anonymous sources, and it is accountable for that process (SPJ Code). ... As I have argued before, if someone recirculates a story, it also owns it. So, in this case, as you say, USA Today, NPR and WaPo (and others) all think this is credible information. So why, again, shouldn't we think it has validity? ...

Comment: No. The power of the keys was given to Peter, and the authority over the community to the Apostles. The Church as the holy people of God is not a Vatican II concept, it dates back to  Judges 20:2 and 2 Samuel 14:13.

To quote Lumen Gentium “Though they differ essentially and not only in degree, the common priesthood of the faithful and the ministerial or hierarchical priesthood are none the less ordered one to another; each in its own proper way shares in the one priesthood of Christ. The ministerial priest, by the sacred power that he has, forms and rules the priestly people; in the person of Christ he effects the eucharistic sacrifice and offers it to God in the name of all the people. The faithful indeed, by virtue of their royal priesthood, participate in the offering of the Eucharist. They exercise that priesthood, too, by the reception of the sacraments, prayer and thanksgiving, the witness of a holy life, abnegation and active charity.”

Comment: " ..putting money into the preservation of native languages would be a concrete gesture that could produce equally concrete benefits..."

Well - the money would be appreciated and spent by the language police - but guaranteed without any permanent benefit to the FN - merely preserving isolation and hopeless life style of frustration.

Being multilingual and having been around the globe more often than I wish to count - my experience:
- English is the language of busines, technology, logistics, documentation .... No matter whether you are in China, Japan, Europe .....
- Translation beyond the superficial - involving deep cultural context - is tricky, very expensive and of limited availability. Technical translation is not possible for languages that have not evolved in terms of the Industrial; Revolution and its consequences.
- For any language group to survive requires a critical mass of speakers and their economic independence. My guess would be a minimum of 100 Million + population.

Comment: I do not have the same faith as you do that the money is already there. Currently the largest portion of Medicare is funded by federal income taxes which are very reflective of a progressive tax structure already. 

But it is not just some will pay more and some less, some will receive less coverage and some more. These differences should be stated openly and honestly.

If children are currently covered by a private employer sponsored health plan than the company supplied premiums and the employee supplied premiums are funding the children's coverage. If "Medicare for All" is funded by increased taxes for the employer and increased taxes for the employee that seems to leave a gap for all dependent care coverage. The funds to cover dependents will need to come from somewhere.

Again state honestly and succinctly how is coverage changing and from whom and how is the funding being generated. Otherwise "Medicare for All" is not a solution but a deception.

Comment: Having reviewed the content of the article, I can see the potential drawback of this product  offering. -However- It has been a useful product for me. A Schedule 'A' bank offered me a 'HELC' after I put down $50K to purchase a $ 177K home purchase at 3.7%  in '2010'; interest only payments if I wanted. I chose principal and interest payments. -Then- In '2015' it was suggested that I take out a mortgage for the residual amount owing on the HELC at 2.24% ; continue paying principal and interest, and save approximately $16 K in interest . -Now- I was informed that I could borrow against the increasing HELC credit portion available but at 3.7% interest rate. -Although- The rate was better than a unsecured/ secured L/C, I have not now nor ever intend to do so. -And- When the mortgage comes up for renewal in '2018', if the rate is not better than 2.24%; i.e. if the rates go up, I can always convert it back to the HELC at the fixed at 3.7% at no cost. No problem  in my case that I can see.

Comment: Unless I missed it in all the comments, I'm surprised no one has addressed the real can of worms opened by this article. The problem for the Catholic Church, as with Judaism and Islam, was called out for the world to see in the Diet of Worms in 1521 by Johann Eck, assistant to the Archbishop of Trier and spokesman for Emperor Charles V, when he addressed Martin Luther:  'there is no one of the heresies which have torn the bosom of the church, which has not derived its origin from the various interpretation of the Scripture. The Bible itself is the arsenal whence each innovator has drawn his deceptive arguments." The Bible, like the Quran, is full of the relics of bad theology. God by definition cannot have a "change of heart," but clearly over the span of time the Bible was written, less so for the Quran (which is puzzling, given its many conflicting commands toward peace and Jihad), the people's understanding of their God changed.  Unfortunately, the Church left these relics in place.

Comment: Absolutely agreed.

Both assault and sexual assault see some common issues that work directly against getting convictions.  In both crimes, alcohol is involved in a gross majority of the cases, undermining the quality of testimony, substantially. In both crimes, the vast majority produce no corroborating physical evidence because there's no injuries. 98% of all sexual assaults reported last year had no injuries (type 1), for example. In addition, there's 3rd party witnesses in only a small fraction of the cases for both crimes.  There's generally slightly better chances for witnesses and visible injuries with assault, so the conviction rate is slightly higher, on average, but neither crime sees greater than half of the court cases get a guilty verdict.

Comment: ""It would be different pools under different rules," said one senior health policy source..."

Literally the definition of how every other type of insurance works. You select the coverage you determine you need based on your own calculated risk of possible but unlikely events you cannot (or do not want to) realistically save to cover, and are pooled with other similarly situated persons (based on the insurer's actuarial data) to pay costs directly related to the calculated risk they take that you or a significant number of fellow poolees might actually need to use the plan.  If you want broader coverage, you are free to pay for more.

Comment: Dear Abby is missing the point when he says file it under 'her problems'. Fine advice if it was just the sister at risk. As to what advice to give, that would depend on whether the parents - even at this late stage - are prepared to grow a spine. It's more likely though that she owns nothing but the debt, in which case I would predict this will end badly for everyone - except of course the scum boyfriend.

Comment: A firm justification for laws limiting the freedom of citizens is the protection of others who might be adversely affected.  In the case of alcohol, there is a potential danger of drunken driving and other acts committed under the influence.  Good laws do not limit individual freedom unless it significantly advances the safety or rights of the general population.  In the present instance, the purchase and use of cigarettes by the younger population does not significantly impact the safety or rights of the general population.  Therefore this restriction on freedom does not conform to good democratic practice.  The dangers of second hand smoke are addressed by other laws prohibiting smoking in various places.  This law represents only the limitation of individual freedom because of the opinions and preferences of others.  In a free society, limitations on freedom should be avoided except when absolutely necessary.

Comment: MC, First, this site purports to use some mix of "NEA, job survey and private data" to come up with their numbers. In their own words, it's "tricky business". Second, the numbers aren't actual salaries, but are a "comfort index" which tries to give a weighted metric vis a vis cost of living(which can vary a lot within states). Hardly "hard data" to make a policy decision off of, but perhaps useful for rookie teachers looking for work, maybe.  Just having starting and average salaries doesn't tell you the whole story. Averages can be skewed by very  high/low earners, a more useful number is median salary. And again, it doesn't address the total compensation issue, or any other factors that are involved that make one state's situation different from anothers. Still waiting for that comprehensive study to be dug up. I think I'll be waiting a while.

Comment: People who have committed crimes are many things.  Mainly they are people.  Human beings.

I know a man who once stole a car while high on drugs.  He was 23.  Was caught, spent a few months in jail.  Convicted of a felony.
He is now 55.  He has grown children.  Has worked construction for 25 years.  Helps his neighbors, is nice to puppies.
How shall we label him?  Is he a "criminal?"  A roofer?  A father?  A human being who once made some stupid decisions and did some bad things??
I know another man who hit his girl in college.   She did not charge him.  He became a naval officer, a good man.
What defines YOUR life?  The bulk of what you have done, or the worst, most horrible time of your life?  Years of hard work and service, or a moment of stupid anger??
We dehumanize people with labels like "criminal" or "felon" or "ex-con."  We lump diverse people with diverse problems into one easily discarded box.   
My convict friend has never judged another person as unworthy of redemption.

On average black people, who comprise just more than 10% of the population, whose drug use is half that of whites, are arrested three times as often on drug charges as whites. So, the higher rate of drug use in the Caucasian population that outnumbers the minority population by almost ten to one, means that black people are arrested on drug charges at a rate of 20 times that of white people for the same offense.  Again, it seems that if people are concerned about illegal drug use and distribution, the Caucasian population is where the action is.

Comment: It seems to me that certain senior Liberals are more concerned about pandering to the wishes of insurance industry lobbyists on Bill S-201 than they are about protecting the interests of Canadians and the Charter rights of individuals. The US, UK, all other G7 countries and UNESCO already prohibit genetic discrimination. No insurance companies have gone bankrupt as a result. 

Approximately 91% of Canadians polled feel that insurance companies should not be allowed access to their genetic information for an insurance assessment. Further, 90% of Canadians opposed the notion that employers should have access to the genetic information of workers or job applicants.

We all know that corporations control our MPs through their 'political donations', but it's a little much to have the Prime Minister so cravenly demonstrating where his allegiance lies. Can he not do the right thing for a change? Protect our individual privacy and honour Liberal campaign promises!

Comment: In this story the reporters imply there is something wrong with the way police classify reports of sexual assault that is in some way harmful to the victims. To me that is the fake news element of this story. 

This story is all about how some cases are classified. Unfounded may be a catchall for those cases where there is no possibility of a successful prosecution. This may be beneficial to the victims since it does not identify why the cases are so classified, thereby protecting the victim from scrutiny.

I foresee as a result of this story that the police may redefine unfounded claims as one or more of the following categories;

-insufficient evidence
-inconclusive evidence
-questionable evidence
-victim unwillingness/inability to provide evidence

Will this be better? I doubt it.

Whatever they do the results will likely not lead to any more charges or convictions. For that to happen laws must be changed to make offenders guilty until proven innocent.

Comment: The Globe article headline is "Doctors warn thousands could leave for U.S. over new federal tax hikes".  This is a misstatement.  There are no "new taxes"  for doctors. It appears some doctors have discovered a loophole to avoid the existing taxes by multiple use  of a small business rate.  The government is closing the loophole, so the doctors now have to pay what they should have done all along, in common with most other Canadians.

I find it unbelievable that many doctors would want to move to the USA because they were denied a loophole in their taxes.  This would imply that these doctors have no commitment to Canada or our way of life, and few if any family ties to keep them here.  Does the Globe really have evidence that many doctors would move, or is it just an imaginary claim in order to create more sensational articles?

Comment: Has it been proved in court that covering one's face is a religious practice? It is a cultural practice but it is not at all clear that it is religious. It is not mentioned in the Koran.

Note that the only part of the burqa that is disputed is the face veil. Nobody is telling the women that they can't wear the baggy black dress that covers the rest of them.

Would we say that we have to allow Sharia law (in which a woman's testimony is worth a fraction of a man's) because it's associated with a certain religion? Would we say that we have to allow men to beat their wives if that is part of their religion?

While we should allow as much personal freedom as we can, it makes sense that there must be limits on face-hiding.

Hiding the face is female oppression. It is a shameful practice that affects the standing of all women.

Comment: You are right, the Church did not deal with this matter in a comprehensive way. I don't think there is a single reason for this. 

Although child sexual abuse (CSA) is and has been a widespread phenomenon both culturally and historically, civil society did not deal with it comprehensively until very recently either. 

The age to marry in the RCC according to CCL has been 14 for the longest time. So sexual contact with people fifteen and up could have been explained away as sexual misconduct/sin, and not abuse, that could be fixed by spiritual means (confession, prayer, etc). Remember,  the overwhelming cases of abuse involved postpubertal individuals.

Every institution has a basic reflex to protect itself. Add to this the fear and disdain of scandal in the RCC, and the high regard for the secrecy of the confessional, and you have a strong incentive to keep things private or secret.

These are just a few reasons, but none of this justifies anything. But it is worth considering them.

Comment: The CDC reports that there are about 20 million cases of Norovirus in the U.S. every year, a large fraction of them from restaurants.  "Infected food workers are frequently the source of these outbreaks, often by touching ready-to-eat foods, such as raw fruits and vegetables, with their bare hands before serving them."  Using gloves is no panacea, true, but it will help.  What would help even more would be a requirement that food workers be given paid sick leave.  Food workers are generally poorly paid as it is, and it is a hardship for them to take off from work when they are ill, so they have a strong incentive to come to work even when ill.  Many outbreaks of Norovirus are traced to this kind of situation.

Comment: If two thirds of Canadians do indeed support climate change action (questionable), and if it is a question of how carbon pricing is implemented rather than if (again not fully convinced), then the best proposed plan so far is Michael Chong's national revenue neutral carbon tax.  

Chong's proposal is similar to the BC model, but it is initially revenue negative as large income and corporate tax cuts come first and the carbon price rises in a gradual predictable manner.  In turn a significant amount of government overhead on green funding programs is eliminated, so that markets are left to come up with solutions given the tax signals. 

Trudeau's approach layers carbon tax on top of existing green programs, and of course his additional intervention and spending.  Don't be fooled when he says revenue neutral, as 3 of 4 provinces (so far) have opted for a tax grab.

Chong is a long shot in the CPC race.  I'd rather have no carbon tax than a poorly designed one like the Trudeau 'plan'.

Comment: ODOT made the correct decision to move Oregon toward faster, more reliable passenger rail service. The decision is consistent with the recommendations of AORTA, the Association of Oregon Rail and Transit Advocates, which has been working for improved passenger service since 1976.

Incremental improvements in frequency, reliability and shortened travel times, NOT top speed is the only true path to higher speed rail.

The Oregon Legislature needs to increase investments to move toward the future. Washington is doing a much better job.

Increasing track capacity in the existing corridor is essential to move both passenger AND freight through our state quickly and reliably.  However, government policies strongly discourages right-of-way and capacity improvements. This MUST change!

Comment: EDITOR’S NOTE: According to information released by King County Elections in 2016, “4 Things You Need to Know About Write-in Candidates in a General Election,” voters have the right to write in the person of their choice. King County Elections staff do count the total number of write-in votes for each office, but they only count how many votes each write-in receives in multi-candidate races if the total number of write-in votes is more than the difference between the top candidates, in which case staff tabulates how many votes each write-in candidate receives for that office. If the write-in candidate has not officially filed for a specific position, the name must be written as the exact spelling. Variations in name spellings will not count as a vote for that person. According to the information, a write-in candidate for mayor defeated the incumbent in the city of Pacific in 2011. For more information, call 206-296-VOTE.

The whole notion of killing juvenile bears and wolves in their dens is alien to me as a white man, who can get most of his food from a  supermarket, restaurant, or fast food joint – because I am in a location and have the money to do so.

No one will congratulate the feds I'm trying to find a good balance if it doesn't work out – but I congratulate them for making the effort!

Comment: While I firmly believe that the community has a moral obligation treat the homeless with compassion and help them move into permanent housing, I also believe the homeless have a corresponding responsibility to the community at large.  They should not engage in activities which deprive the public of enjoyment of our public spaces and they should not endanger our biggest industry.  If homelessness were to have a serious impact on tourism it would threaten the jobs of many people who themselves are only a few paychecks away from being homeless – and many of the homeless I have interviewed have said the same thing themselves.  I believe it is one reason that most of the homeless in Waikiki are not locals – and yet, in response to Crystal’s point- it is an urban myth that the majority of our homeless come here from the mainland.  Close to 90% of the homeless had a residence in Hawaii before they became homeless.  (Apologies for the verbosity!)

Comment: I think that Maggie should have put her pen down after the bit about luck. It is the determining factor in terms of where and to whom you were born. Managing the benefit of good luck is natural to most people. Most people born into a lucky situation obviously make the most of it. Most people who aren't as lucky also strive to improve their lot and society has never provided the level of opportunity to do so than exists today. Upward mobility exists to a far greater extent for those who were not born within the '1 %'.
